text: Code-style for indent of multi-line IF statement in Python?
When indenting long if conditions, you usually do something like this (actually, PyDev indents like that):

code:
if (collResv.repeatability is None or
    collResv.somethingElse):
    collResv.rejected = True
    collResv.rejectCompletely()

text: However, this puts the block started by the if statement on the same indentation level as the last part of the if condition which makes it very ugly/hard to read in my opinion as you don't immediately see where the block starts.
Some other styles I thought about:

code:
if (collResv.repeatability is None or
        collResv.somethingElse):
    collResv.rejected = True
    collResv.rejectCompletely()

text: This looks pretty inconsistent as the second lie is indented much more than the first line but it's readable.

code:
if (collResv.repeatability is None or
  collResv.somethingElse):
    collResv.rejected = True
    collResv.rejectCompletely()

text: This is also more readable than the first example, but the indentation is not a multiple of 4 anymore and besides that it looks wrong as the second line has less indentation than the beginning of the condition in the first line.
So, my main question is: Is there a suggested indentation style for cases like that which do not require overly-long lines (i.e.
If not, what do you prefer for cases like that?
